Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Situation2: They strictly follow a detailed schedule of daily prayers, chanting, and offerings, ensuring nothing is skipped.
Story: I was deep into debugging a minor UI glitch that our QA team flagged. It wasn’t critical—users could easily work around it—but my manager wanted it fixed before the next release. I glanced at the clock. My daily puja time was approaching, and I never missed it. The incense, the chanting, the offerings—they grounded me, gave me peace. But the code was stubborn, and I could feel the pressure mounting as messages from the team pinged in. “Any update?” “Can you push the fix today?” My mind raced between the lines of code and the rituals waiting for me at home. I knew my family expected me to uphold our traditions, to be present and focused during prayers. Yet, my team needed me to be present here, to deliver. The weight of both worlds pressed on my chest, and I sat frozen, torn between the demands of my faith and my work, unsure which part of myself to let down.
